revision.text:
{{Infobox company | logo= F10 company logo.jpg | logo_size= 200px | type= [[Privately held company|Private]] | location_city = | foundation= [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] (2016) | name =F10 | key_people= Markus Graf (founder)
Andreas Iten (co-founder)
| homepage= {{url|http://www.f10.ch/}} }} '''F10''' is a startup incubator and accelerator founded in 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.fintech.finance/01-news/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-opens-applications-for-its-acceleration-program/|title=F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator Opens Applications for its Acceleration Program|date=2017-02-17|work=Fintech Finance|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/2016/11/f10-accelerator-programme-calls-for-fintech-start-ups/|title=F10 accelerator programme calls for fintech start-ups|work=FinTech Futures|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-gb}}{{Cite web|url=https://irishtechnews.ie/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-calls-for-2018-p2-applicants/|title=F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator calls for 2018 P2 Applicants – Irish Tech News|website=irishtechnews.ie|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-04}} Its accelerator programs, helps startups in connecting with the other Swiss entrepreneurs, experts, mentors and investors for the early stage venture and late stage venture investing.{{Cite news|url=https://www.siliconluxembourg.lu/zurich-based-fintech-incubator-and-accelerator-f10-to-explore-luxembourg/|title=Zurich based FinTech Incubator and Accelerator F10 to Explore Luxembourg|date=2017-11-24|work=Silicon Luxembourg|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.meetup.com/Swiss-FinTech-Meetup-Lugano/events/244746389/?_cookie-check=du-dg78fzvA6fLIO|title=Meet the F10 incubator & accelerator in Lugano|work=Meetup|access-date=2018-02-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.baloise.com/en/home/media/news/2017/baloise-joins-fintech-incubator-and-accelerator-f10.html|title=Baloise joins fintech incubator and accelerator 'F10' - Baloise Group|website=Baloise|language=en|access-date=2018-02-04}} The company is a [[non-profit organization]] and based in [[Zurich]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.fintechfestival.sg/exhibitor/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator/|title=F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator {{!}} Singapore FinTech Festival|date=2017-10-09|work=Singapore FinTech Festival|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://gust.com/accelerators/f10-incubator-accelerator|title=F10 Incubator & Accelerator - Gust|website=Gust|access-date=2018-02-04}} ==History== In 2014, SIX (Switzerland’s stock exchange) launched a new project to accelerate their innovation process which grew into F10 and it was formally launched as [[Fintech|FinTech]] Startup Incubator / Accelerator in August 2015 by Markus Graf and Andreas Iten.{{Cite news|url=http://fintechnews.ch/fintech/swiss-f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-prepares-demo-day/14748/|title=Swiss F10 Fintech Incubator and Accelerator Prepares for Demo Day|date=2017-12-05|work=Fintech Schweiz Digital Finance News - FintechNewsCH|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.moneycab.com/2017/09/11/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-calls-for-2018-p2-applicants/|title=Moneycab › F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator calls for 2018 P2 Applicants|last=Moneycab|date=2017-09-11|access-date=2018-02-04|language=de}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.techbullion.com/f10-opens-applications-fintech-accelerator-program/|title=F10 Opens Applications for Fintech Accelerator Program {{!}} TechBullion|website=Techbullion|access-date=2018-02-04}} F10 launched the 6-month “Prototype to Product” P2 program and held its first program in July 2017 in which 14 startups was selected from 260 international teams from the financial, Insurance and regulatory technology sector.{{Cite web|url=https://www.startupticker.ch/en/news/june-2017/14-startups-selected-for-f10-s-accelerator-program|title=14 Startups selected for F10’s Accelerator Program Startupticker.ch {{!}} The Swiss Startup News channel|website=Startupticker|language=en|access-date=2018-02-04}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.itone.lu/actualites/eri-has-joined-f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-0|title=ERI has joined the F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator|website=Itone.lu|language=fr|access-date=2018-02-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/71894/swiss-fintech-incubator-and-accelerator-f10-calls-for-applicants-for-third-startup-batch|title=Swiss fintech incubator and accelerator F10 calls for applicants for third startup batch|last=Finextra|date=2017-12-08|work=Finextra Research|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en}} F10 accelerator program investors include SIX, PwC Switzerland, [[Julius Bär]], Raiffeisen, [[Zürcher Kantonalbank]], [[Baloise Group]], Generali Group Switzerland, ERI Bancaire and eny Finance that helps startups promising ideas into a company.{{Cite news|url=https://paymentweek.com/2017-11-17-f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-gains-zurcher-kantonalbank-corporate-member/|title=F10 Fintech Incubator & Accelerator Gains ZÜRCHER KANTONALBANK as Corporate Member {{!}} Payment Week|date=2017-11-17|work=Payment Week|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.seca.ch/Calendar/Events/2017/F10-Fintech-Incubator-Accelerator-Investor-Day.aspx|title=F10 Fintech Incubator & Accelerator - Investor Day {{!}} SECA {{!}} Swiss Private Equity & Corporate Finance Association|website=www.seca.ch|access-date=2018-02-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.crowdfundinsider.com/2018/01/127364-fintech-incubator-accelerator-f10-names-switzerland-banking-group-raiffeisen-programs-latest-corporate-member/|title=Fintech Incubator & Accelerator F10 Names Switzerland Banking Group Raiffeisen The Program's Latest Corporate Member {{!}} Crowdfund Insider|date=2018-01-22|work=Crowdfund Insider|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}} Notable investments include Appetita, CashSentinel, Data XL, Riskifier and Brainalyzed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizstuff.co/blog/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-interview-with-bizgees|title=F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator – Interview with BizGees|website=Strategy Support for Entrepreneurs|access-date=2018-02-04}} ==Structure== Startups can apply for Prototype to Product” P2 program and their viability is judged by the Managing Director of the program, in which startups will be supported in transitioning their prototype to a sellable product.{{Cite news|url=http://ftreporter.com/f10-fintech-incubator-accelerator-opens-for-applications/|title=F10 FinTech Incubator & Accelerator Opens For Applications|last=ftreporter|work=FT Reporter|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US}} Each team will be supported by a coach from the F10 team and external mentor. Once the teams are selected into its accelerator program, they have access to working space at F10 in Zurich.{{Cite web|url=http://fintechnews.ch/tag/f10-incubator-and-accelerator/|title=F10 Incubator and Accelerator Archives {{!}} Fintech Schweiz Digital Finance News - FintechNewsCH|website=Fintech Schweiz Digital Finance News - FintechNewsCH|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-04}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Mentorships]] [[Category:Startup accelerators]]

revision.comment: lowercase title
revision.text:
{{lowercase title}} {{Infobox Organization |name = |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = Students support teachers in solving IT-problems and working with digital media in class |formation = 2001 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = Frankfurt, Hessen, DE |region_served = Frankfurt |membership = Schools |language = |leader_title = Project Manager |leader_name = Dr. Thomas Knaus |main_organ = |parent_organization = University of Applied Science |affiliations = School Department of the City of Frankfurt |num_staff = 20 |num_volunteers = |budget = non-profit |website = [http://www.fraline.de fraLine] |remarks = }} '''fraLine''' is a non-profit (research) project of [[Frankfurt University of Applied Sciences]].<ref>[http://www.frankfurt-university.de/de/fachbereiche/fb2/forschung_institute_projekte/fraline.html Project on the Website of the Frankfurt University of Applied Sciences]</ref> Project and research activities focus on IT services management for schools and the use of digital media in educational settings. fraLine is also a joint project between the University of Applied Sciences and the city of [[Frankfurt]] am Main (represented by the "Stadtschulamt" = municipal school-maintaining body).<ref>[http://www.frankfurt.de/sixcms/detail.php?id=4096&_ffmpar_id_inhalt=20557 City of Frankfurt website]</ref> fraLine and the city of Frankfurt cooperate in the fields of IT support and IT service management in educational contexts as well as technical implementation of digital media in class. fraLine also cooperates with the Hessian state education authority ("[[:de:Staatliches Schulamt|Staatliches Schulamt]]") in the field of media education and digital media training for teachers. fraLine was launched in 2001 and employs mainly technical students of the University of Applied Sciences and [[Goethe University Frankfurt]], but also IT professionals, engineers and media educators.<ref>cf. [http://www.thomas-knaus.de Dr. Thomas Knaus] and [http://fraline.de/personen/team fraLine team page]</ref>
==Research and development projects==
===Projects=== fraLine conducts research in the fields of [[IT service management]] according to [[ITIL]] recommendations<ref>cf. e.g. [http://fraline.de/images/Downloads/Qualifikationsarbeiten/diplomarbeit_itil_schmelz_09Aug.pdf "Analysis of ITSM elements in the technical support for schools of a major school-maintaining body as to their consistency with ITIL recommendations" by Anthony Schmelz]</ref> as well as in the field of IT support and digital media use in educational contexts including [[educational software]], [[media literacy]] etc. Research results and concepts are provided to the city of Frankfurt ("Stadtschulamt") for the improvement of information technology in schools and the establishment of a centrally managed school IT infrastructure in the municipal area. Therefore, fraLine also offers advisory services to the city of Frankfurt, to all municipal schools as well as other educational institutions on topics such as acquisition of computers or computer parts, hardware, IT security, remote service etc.
Research in technical areas is complemented by studies in media education.<ref>[http://www.thomas-knaus.de/index.php/en/research Research projects by Dr. Thomas Knaus]</ref> Results in the field of media education and current media projects are presented on the annual expert conference "fraMediale"<ref>The list of speakers in 2009 included the mayor of Frankfurt Mrs. [[Jutta Ebeling]] and the President of the University of Applied Sciences Frankfurt Dr.-Ing. [[Detlev Buchholz]] as well as several representatives of "Project Lehr@mt" at Frankfurt Goethe University [http://www.zlf.uni-frankfurt.de/wir-ueber-uns/neue-medien/index.html "Project Lehr@mt"]</ref><ref>[http://www.framediale.de Conference webpage]</ref> which is hosted and organized by fraLine.<ref>A conference volume is published by "kopaed" (German publishing house) under the title [http://www.kopaed.de/kopaedshop/index.php?PRODUCT_ID=697 "fraMediale - digitale Medien in Bildungseinrichtungen"]</ref>
fraLine developed the "fraDesk", a multi-user capable [[trouble ticket system]] for coordinating and documenting customer requests, incident reports or general processes based on division of labor. fraLine uses this software in its own everyday routine. The "fraDesk" is free software and was presented at the [[CeBIT]] 2008 in [[Hanover]], Germany.
Other research projects conducted by fraLine employees<ref>cp. [http://www.fraline.de/index.php/en/publications/academic-papers-and-reports List of publications on the project webpage]</ref> include the development of standard resource administration and user management for schools, improvement of school support via remote maintenance and support, but also media educational topics such as content filtering, evaluation of [[educational software]] and media communication.<ref>[http://www.kopaed.de/kopaedshop/index.php?PRODUCT_ID=637 "Kommunigrafie - eine empirische Studie zur Bedeutung von Text und Bild in der digitalen Kommunikation" ("An empirical study concerning the meaning of text and image in digital communication") by Dr. Thomas Knaus ]</ref>
===Knowledge base for teachers=== fraLine publishes relevant information for schools as well as research results in the form of test reports and academic papers,<ref>[http://www.fraline.de/index.php/en/publications Test reports and academic papers]</ref> a glossary,<ref>[http://www.fraline.de/index.php/de/glossar Glossary]</ref> and a large set of FAQ.<ref>[http://fraline.de/faq/ fraLine "FAQ" knowledge database"]</ref> The FAQ database is a practical [[knowledge base]] [[Knowledge base]] and used as a point of reference for local teachers and others. It includes technical tutorials and information on the Frankfurt local school network, operating systems, software, hardware, peripheral equipment, the Internet, licenses and rights of utilization. Additionally, fraLine offers tutorials and introductory courses imparting theoretical and practical knowledge to school teachers and school IT representatives in Frankfurt.<ref>cf. Online platform for providers of seminars and workshops in Frankfurt hosted by the state education authority ("Staatliches Schulamt für die Stadt Frankfurt am Main") [http://www.medienbildung-frankfurt.de/ "Regionale Medienbildung"]</ref>
==Support services for schools== The fraLine student team offers practical IT support to all 152 schools in Frankfurt by operating a telephone hotline, the Internet-based helpdesk "fraDesk" and through on-site service. Financed by public funds through the city of Frankfurt the service is free of charge for schools. It covers everyday troubleshooting relating to [[computer hardware|hardware]] and [[software]], as well as software installation, actualisation and handling. In order to coordinate its support services, fraLine cooperates with so-called "IT representatives" in every school. They are appointed by their school principals and responsible for collecting IT-incidents and requests in their schools and communicating them to fraLine. Here, fraLine functions as first point of contact ("single-point-of-contact"). If problems cannot be solved by telephone, fraLine employees visit schools on-site or help them to refer their request to the competent authorities (e.g. school maintaining body ("Stadtschulamt"), or the Department of Information and Communicational Technology).<ref>e.g. the Deutschherrenschule (secondary school in Frankfurt) includes fraLine in its [http://www.schuleundzukunft.de/fileadmin/user_upload/Medienschulen/Medienkonzept_Deutschherrenschule.pdf "media concept" (page 3f.)]</ref> It is sometimes criticized that IT-support carried out by students does not match the schools´ need for a "professional" support. On the other hand, only senior students who are identified as possessing the necessary qualifications are accepted at the project. In addition to the technical support, fraLine also offers training courses for teachers and school administration staff in the fields of IT-infrastructure and media use in educational contexts.<ref>cf. Online platform for providers of seminars and workshops in Frankfurt hosted by the state education authority ("Staatliches Schulamt für die Stadt Frankfurt am Main") [http://www.medienbildung-frankfurt.de/ "Regionale Medienbildung"]</ref> As another way to support schools, fraLine launched the project "educational-technical assistance". As part of this project, fraLine employees accompany teachers during class offering them technical assistance with the digital media devices they plan to use in their lesson. The project aims at reducing technical insecurities of teachers and wants to promote a broader use of digital media in education.
==Partnerships, cooperations and awards== fraLine contributes to various multi-organisational and interdisciplinary initiatives in Frankfurt am Main, in the federal state of Hesse and in Germany responding to the growing demand for a sensible use of media in education. Thus, fraLine maintains close partnerships with its sister projects in Bremen<ref>[http://www.schul-support-service.de/ School support service in the city of Bremen "S3"]</ref> and Hamburg.<ref>[http://3s.hh.schule.de/ School support service in the city of Hamburg "3S"]</ref> In 2007, fraLine was awarded with the "Germany – Land of Ideas" award. "Land of Ideas" is an initiative under the patronage of former German Federal President [[Horst Köhler]]. Public or private institutions that have developed innovations and ideas are nominated as so-called "landmarks in the land of ideas" for one year.<ref>[http://www.land-of-ideas.org/CDA/landmark_of_the_day,6482,1,,en.html?action=detail&id=3303 ''Land of Ideas'' (June 10, 2008), "A Win-Win Situation"]</ref>
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==Web resources== * [http://www.fraline.de fraLine webpage] * [http://www.frankfurt.de/sixcms/detail.php?id=4096&_ffmpar%5B_id_inhalt%5D=20557 City of Frankfurt] * [http://www.thomas-knaus.de/index.php/de/publikationen List of publications by Dr. Thomas Knaus] * [http://www.fh-frankfurt.de/de/fachbereiche/fb2/forschung_institute_projekte/fraline.html Frankfurt University of Applied Sciences] * [http://idw-online.de/pages/de/news262412 Academic Information Service] * [http://grundschule.bildung.hessen.de/fb_gsnm/FB_Bericht/FFM/FFM_4.html EducationServer Hessen] * [http://www.fraline.de/images/stories/fraLineData/fraLine/Presseschau/bild_hallo_schueler.pdf ''Bild'' (January 19, 2002), "Hallo Schüler, wir sind eure Internet-Helfer"] * [http://www.fraline.de/images/stories/fraLineData/fraLine/Presseschau/fr_beim_computerkollaps_bietet_die_fachhochschule_erste_hilfe.pdf ''Frankfurter Rundschau''(February 20, 2002) "Beim Computerkollaps bietet die Fachhochschule Erste Hilfe"] * [http://www.fraline.de/images/stories/fraLineData/fraLine/Presseschau/fr_locker_erst_nach_der_loesung.pdf ''Frankfurter Rundschau''(March 14, 2003) "Locker erst nach der Lösung"] * [http://www.ifib.de/publikationsdateien/Fraline-Endbericht-020903.pdf Report on fraLine and IT support for schools in Frankfurt by the "Institute for Information Management Bremen GmbH (ifib)"] * [http://www.medienbildung-frankfurt.de Medienbildung Frankfurt] * [http://www.schule-mit-zukunft.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-188/_nr-4/_p-1/i.html Schule@Zukunft - media education project in Hessia] * [https://www.welt.de/wams_print/article2078935/Eine_Hand_waescht_die_andere.html Welt Online - Eine Hand wäscht die andere] * [http://www.forschung-fuer-die-praxis.de/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=20&Itemid=22 Online Platform Hessian Universities of Applied Sciences]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fraline}} [[Category:Education in Frankfurt]] [[Category:Information technology education]]

beam={{convert|37.5|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught= |Ship draft= |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth={{convert|22.5|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion= |Ship sail plan= |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity= |Ship troops= |Ship complement= |Ship crew= |Ship notes= }} |} '''''Glenlee''''' is a steel-hulled three-masted [[barque]], built in 1896 for Glasgow owners, trading as a cargo ship.<ref name="Schäuffelen2005" /> From 1922 she was a sail training ship in the Spanish Navy. She is now a [[museum ship]] at the [[Riverside Museum]] on Pointhouse Quay, [[Glasgow]], known as '''The Tall Ship at Glasgow Harbour'''.
== Description ==
''Glenlee'' was built by Anderson Rodger & Company at their Bay Shipyard in [[Port Glasgow]] for the Glen-line of the Glasgow shipping company Archibald Sterling & Co. Ltd., and was launched on 3 December 1896.<ref name="Brown2009">{{cite book|author=Paul Brown|title=Britain's Historic Ships: A Complete Guide to the Ships that Shaped the Nation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=moZ-uEETj1QC&pg=PA48|date=4 August 2009|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|isbn=978-1-84486-093-7|pages=48–49}}</ref> She has a hull length of {{convert|245.5|ft|m|abbr=on}}, beam of {{convert|37.5|ft|m|abbr=on}} and depth of {{convert|22.5|ft|m|abbr=on}}, the [[o/a|over-all]] length with the spike bowsprit is {{convert|282|ft|m|abbr=on}}.
She has 1,613 GRT and 1,490 NRT.{{clarify|reason=Not same as listed in infobox; which is correct?|date=August 2014}} Rigged only with double topgallant sails over double top sails, she was not equipped with [[royal (sail)|royal sails]] (baldheader rigging) to save costs concerning gear and seamen. As with many baldheaded sailing ships the square sails were a little wider than the sails of a standard rigging to gain sail area for a better propulsion.
== Career == [[File:Glenlee at Riverside Museum.jpg|200px|thumb|left|''Glenlee'' docked at her new home outside the [[Riverside Museum]], Glasgow.]] On 13 December 1896, just ten days after she was launched fully rigged and seaworthy, her maiden voyage brought her in [[ballast tank|ballast]] to [[Liverpool]] and from there with a general cargo to [[Portland, Oregon]]. For 23 years she traded as a bulk cargo carrier under the [[Civil ensign|Red Ensign]] via [[Cape of Good Hope]] to [[Australia]], returning via [[Cape Horn]], firstly under the ownership of Archibald Sterling and Co, Glasgow, then as ''Islamount'' of Islamount Sailing Ship Co Ltd (Robert Ferguson & Co), [[Dundee]](1898-1905), and finally with the Flint Castle Shipping Co Ltd (Robert Thomas & Co), Liverpool (1905-1918).
''Islamount'' was renamed the ''Clarastella'' in 1919 when she changed hands to the Star of Italy Italian Shipping Company ({{lang-it|Società Italiana di Navigazione Stella d'Italia}}) of [[Milan]] who registered her in [[Genoa]]. The new owner had her repaired and equipped with two auxiliary diesel engines (1922).
In 1922 the ship came into the hands of the Officers' Military Navy School ({{lang-es|[[Escuela Naval Militar de Oficiales]]}}) as ''Galatea'' to be used as a sail training ship. During this period the ship underwent a lot of changes to her [[hull (watercraft)|hull]] and [[superstructure]]. A flying bridge was installed on the [[poop deck]], a flying jibboom was attached to the spike bowsprit, and many other changes such as the installation of accommodation facilities for 300 cadets.
In April 1931 she became part of the [[Spanish Republican Navy]]. At the time of the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|coup of July 1936]] she was at sea and reached [[Ferrol, Galicia|Ferrol]], a harbour that had been taken by the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist faction]].
== Preservation ==
After more than 47 years of service as a sail and later on as a stationary training ship she was first laid up in [[A Graña]], Ferrol, her Spanish port of registry. In 1981 the underwater hull was re-plated at the drydock in Ferrol. Later ''Galatea'' was completely de-rigged down to a hulk (all yards with standing and running rigging and even the masts removed) and was towed to [[Seville]] to be used as a floating museum, but left forgotten. Some sources{{which|date=August 2014}} even reported that the ship was sunk in the harbour by removing her bronze sea cock valve, but salvaged later by the Spanish Navy.
In any case, the ship was in such poor condition that it was eventually decided to scrap her. In 1990 a British naval architect (Dr. Sir John Brown, 1901-2000) discovered the ship and in 1993 she was rescued from being scrapped and subsequently bought by the Clyde Maritime Trust at auction for ₧5000,000 or £40,000. After making the hull seaworthy (all openings on deck were closed and the flying bridge spanning the poop deck during her service in Spain and the attached flying jibboom were removed) the ship was returned to Glasgow months later in tow from Seville. [[File:Glenlee figurehead.jpg|200px|thumb|left|''Glenlee''{{'}}s figurehead "Mary Doll".]] After preliminary works in dry-dock such as the removal of the unnecessary propellers, the check and repair of all the plates below the waterline and new paint, a six-year-long process of restoration began including a new cut wooden figurehead, a complete set of new rigging including the re-assembling and re-stepping of her original masts and re-crossing of the old yards (1998), as well as many other replacements (original deckhouses) and repairs. Her old masts and many of the old yards, which still existed somewhere in Spain, were given back by the Spanish when they realized that the old ship would be really renewed to her original "Cape Horn status", painted grey again with "gun ports".{{clarify|reason=Why scare quotes?|date=August 2014}}
Except for the hull a new ship had to be rebuilt. All the changes made to the ship by the Spanish and previous owners had to be removed, such as all the cabins built for the trainees and a lot of scrap iron ballast in the frames of the holds. First of all she was given back her original name, ''Glenlee'', by the Lord Provost of Glasgow on 6 July 1993 when the ship arrived in Glasgow for the first time since her launch in 1896 at her old and new port of registry - Glasgow Harbour. ''Glenlee'' is now recognised as part of the [[National Historic Fleet]].
As a museum ship and tourist attraction, ''Glenlee'' offers educational programmes, events including exhibitions and is a venue for the [[West End Festival]] and volunteering opportunities. Since June 2011, the ship has been open at Glasgow's new [[Riverside Museum]].
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="Schäuffelen2005">{{Citation | last1 = Schäuffelen | first1 = Otmar | title = Chapman Great Sailing Ships Of The World | publisher = Hearst Books | pages = 141–142 | year = 2005 | isbn = 1588163849 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QgMRudqoLGQC&pg=PA141 | postscript= . }}</ref> }}
==External links== *[http://www.thetallship.com/ ''Glenlee'' - the Tallship official website] *[http://www.clydeships.co.uk/view.php?year_built=&builder=&ref=19404&vessel=GLENLEE ''Glenlee'' at Clyde-Built Database] *[http://www.rampantscotland.com/visit/blvisitglenlee.htm ''Glenlee'' at the Clyde Maritime Centre, Glasgow] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080404222023/http://freespace.virgin.net/r.cadwalader/maritime/era/islamount.htm ''Glenlee'' in times as ''Islamount''] *[http://www.thesquarerigger.com/glenlee.html square-rigger site of the ''Glenlee'', a well-documented site of its restoration history] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080923223157/http://sailing-ships.oktett.net/671.html ''Glenlee'' on sailing-ships.oktett.net] *[http://www.clydewaterfrontheritage.com/thetallship_2.aspx The Tall Ship, Glenlee - Clyde Waterfront Heritage] {{National Historic Ships}} {{Clyde-built tall ships still afloat|state=collapsed}} {{Surviving ocean going ships}} {{coord|55|51|52.1|N|4|18|25.0|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Commons category|Glenlee (ship, 1896)}}

revision.comment: /* External links */ replace [[Category:Cultural heritage]] with [[Category:Cultural heritage of Germany]] to assist with the tidy up of the former category
revision.text:
{{Hatnote|Not to be confused with [[Goseck]], a nearby municipality.}}{{Infobox building | name = Goseck | landlord = Foundation „Dome und Schlösser Sachsen-Anhalt“ | map_type = Germany | building_type = Monastery | location = Saxony-Anhalt | location_country = Germany
| coordinates = {{coord|51|11|25|N|11|52|11|E|type:landmark_region:DE-ST|display=inline,title}} }}
Goseck, a [[monastery]] built on the foundations of a [[castle]], as well as the [[vineyard]] of Dechantenberg is located in the municipality of Goseck of [[Saxony-Anhalt]] in [[Germany]]. It has been proposed by Germany for inscription in the List of [[World Heritage]]. The World Heritage nomination [[Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut]] is representative for the processes that shaped the continent during the [[High Middle Ages]] between 1000 and 1300: [[Christianization]], the so-called “[[Landesausbau]]” and the dynamics of cultural exchange and transfer characteristic for this very period.<ref name="Bartlett">{{cite book|last=Bartlett|first=Robert|title=The Making of Europe: Conquest, Colonization and Cultural Change 950-1350|date=1994|publisher=Penguin}}</ref>
== World Heritage Nomination == Goseck and its vineyard is one of the eleven components of the cultural landscape [[Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut]]. Together with the agricultural features on the northern slopes of the Saale and the sandstone quarries used for the building of the monastery, this ensemble conveys the different forms of land use of the [[medieval]] monastery structures.<ref>UNESCO (2017): WHC/17/41.COM/INF.8B1.{{cite book|title=Nominations to the World Heritage List (Krakow, 2017).|publisher= UNESCO press|page=54|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Vineyard Steinmeister.jpg|thumb|Vineyard Steinmeister]] Goseck Castle was part of a network of [[Franks|Frankish]] [[castles]] on the [[Saale]] River. It was founded around the year 800. The counts of Goseck were one of the noblest aristocratic families of the empire in the [[10th Century in Germany|10th]] and [[11th century]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Die Pfalzgrafen von Sachsen bis zum Jahre 1088. ''In:'' Braunschweigisches Jahrbuch 36.|trans-title= The palsgraves of Saxony until the year 1088.''In:'' Yearbook of Braunschweig 36.|page=24–52|author=Starke, Heinz-Dieter|publisher=City of Braunschweig|date=1955|language=German}}</ref> Count Frederick I of Goseck had his center of power in Goseck . In 1041, Adalbert (archbishop of Hamburg-Bremen from 1043) founded a [[Benedictine monastery]] in the eastern part of the noble castle of Goseck. The minster was erected in 1046.<ref>{{cite book|title=Burg, Kloster und Schloss Goseck. Zum Stand der baugeschichtlichen Erforschung. ''In:'' Denkmalpﬂege in Sachsen-Anhalt 7 |trans-title=Castle, monastery and palace Goseck. Research on the building history. In: Preservation of historical monuments in Saxony-Anhalt 7.|page=1–30|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Saxony-Anhalt|date=1999|language=German}}</ref>
== Location == It is situated 9 kilometers northeast of Naumburg across the Saale Valley on the opposite bank. This monastery of the 11th century is a preserved and documented structure of the High Middle Ages. It was built to be visible from afar, offering lines of sight to most of the monuments in the nominated areas.
== Architecture == The [[crypt]] and [[choir]] of the monastery church display the very best of [[Salian]] architecture. Goseck is an example for the transformation of a noble family’s hereditary seat into a monastery with dynastic memorial tasks.<ref>{{cite book|title=Quellen zur Geschichte und Baugeschichte von Burg, Kloster und Schloss Goseck. ''In:'' Saale-Unstrut-Jahrbuch 4. |trans-title=Sources on history and building history of the castle, monastery and palace Goseck. In: Yearbook of Saale-Unstrut 4.|page=28–43|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Saxony-Anhalt|date=1999|language=German}}</ref>
== Viniculture == In the chronicles of the Benedictines of the Goseck monastery the terraced vineyard below the site is dated back to the year 1093; it is the oldest vineyard in continuous use in the nominated region. The Dechantenberg vineyard is exposed to the south.
== Today ==
Around 1540, the monastery was secularized. Since 1997, Goseck is owned by the »Landesstiftung Dome und Schlösser Sachsen-Anhalt«, a state foundation endowed by the State of Saxony-Anhalt . Today, a European Centre for Music and Culture (“Europäisches Musik und Kulturzentrum”) resides in Goseck and offers a range of cultural activities.<ref group=note>For further information: http://www.dome-schloesser.de/.</ref>
==See also== * [[World Heritage Convention]] * [[World Heritage site]] * [[World Heritage Committee]] * [[High Middle Ages]] * [[Cultural landscape|Cultural Landscape]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Notes == {{reflist|30em|group=note}}
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6FPjj5cWWCg Video of the cultural landscape of Naumburg]
[[Category:Cultural heritage of Germany]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:High Middle Ages]] [[Category:Landscape]] [[Category:Saxony-Anhalt]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Use British English|date=February 2018}} {{Orphan|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = | image = HighlandAviationLogolow.jpg | size = 200px | map = Inverness (Location).png | msize = 200px | abbreviation = | motto = | formation = April 2009 | type = [[Flight training|Flying school]] | headquarters = | location = [[Inverness Airport]], Scotland | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = | membership = 275 | leader_title = Director | leader_name = David Barclay | leader_title2 = Head of Training | leader_name2 = Alan Nicholson | key_people = | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.highlandaviation.com HighlandAviation.com] | remarks = | former name = }}
'''Highland Aviation Training Ltd''' is an Authorised Training Facility at [[Inverness Airport]].<ref name=CAAstd31>Civil Aviation Authority. Standards Document 30: Private Pilots Licensing Registered Training Facilities including Seaplane Training Facilities. 10 January 2012. [http://www.caa.co.uk/application.aspx?catid=33&pagetype=65&appid=11&mode=detail&id=1210]</ref>
Highland Aviation provides training towards the [[Pilot licensing in the United Kingdom|EASA/CAA Private Pilots Licence (PPL), the EASA/CAA Light Aircraft Pilot's Licence (LAPL)]] and the CAA UK National Private Pilots Licence (NPPL). It also provides training for the UK CAA IMC rating (EASA IR(R)) and the night rating.<ref name=CAAstd31 />
In addition to these ratings Highland Aviation also provides beach landing courses<ref name=beach>Highland Aviation. The Inverness Flying School. ''Beach Landing course''. [http://www.highlandaviation.com/courses__prices/beach_landing.asp] Retrieved 6 October 2011</ref> and mountain flying training.<ref name=mountain>Highland Aviation. The Inverness Flying School. ''Flying Lessons in the Highlands of Scotland''. [http://www.highlandaviation.com/flying_lessons/flying_in_the_highlands.asp] Retrieved 6 October 2011</ref>
== History == Started in 2009 with a fleet of [[Piper Aircraft]],<ref name =Aircraft>CAA. G-INFO page showing all aircraft registered to Highland Aviation [http://www.caa.co.uk/application.aspx?catid=60&pagetype=65&appid=1&mode=summary&owner=highland%20aviation] Retrieved 5 October 2011</ref> Highland Aviation now has over 300 members.
== Mountain flying == Situated near the [[Cairngorms]] and the [[Scottish Highlands]], Inverness Airport is a suitable place from which to explore and learn to fly around mountains. Highland Aviation offers trial flights and training courses in mountain flying.<ref name=mountain />
[[Ben Nevis]], Scotland's highest mountain, extends up to only 4,409 ft<ref>[http://www.munromagic.com/MountainInfo.cfm?Mountain=1 MunroMagic. Ben Nevis information page]</ref> allowing pilots to experience mountain flying without having to consider the effect of altitude on aircraft performance.<ref>[http://www.pilotfriend.com/training/flight_training/aft_perf.htm PilotFriend. Article discussing performance vs altitude]</ref>
== Beach landings == [[File:GLAZL GBNHG atSollas.jpg|thumb|left|Highland Aviation aircraft<ref name=Aircraft/> at [[Sollas]]]] Beach landing is illegal in most countries without proper permission.<ref name=newyorktimearticle >[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/06/nyregion/06plane.html New York Times. Article concerning pilot who landed on a beach]</ref> With many secluded areas with long sandy beaches, Scotland is one of the few regions in the world where beach landings are possible. Highland Aviation is the only training provider in the UK to offer a dedicated course of beach landing instruction. Most of the course is completed at [[Barra Airport (Scotland)|Barra]] and [[Sollas]].<ref name=beach />
Beach landings are accomplished by using a ''soft field'' approach<ref>[http://flighttraining.aopa.org/students/maneuvers/skills/softfield.html FlightTraining.AOPA. Article discussing Soft Field Landing Techniques]</ref> with power remaining on throughout the procedure. This will result, if executed correctly, in a very smooth touchdown with a high nose attitude. The nose can then be lowered onto the beach gently to avoid digging into the soft sand.
== External links == *[http://www.nationalprivatepilotslicence.co.uk/ National Private Pilots Licence Information] *[http://www.caa.co.uk/ UK Civil Aviation Authority] *[http://www.lightaircraftassociation.co.uk/ UK Light Aircraft Association]
== References ==

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
'''Information Television Network''', also known as '''ITV''', is an American [[television production company]] based in [[Boca Raton, Florida]], founded by Ed and Ana Cristina Lerner in 1992.<ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|title=ITV Selects Scott McFarland, MD As New Host Of Healthy Body, Healthy Mind|url=http://www.filminflorida.com/wh/ViewNewsItem.asp?id=1007|work=The Florida Office of Film and Entertainment|date=September 12, 2008|quote=ITV was founded in 1992 by Ed and Ana Cristina Lerner with a vision to...|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120052811/http://filminflorida.com/wh/ViewNewsItem.asp?id=1007|archivedate=January 20, 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> The company specializes in creating health and wellness documentary-style programming and is best known for producing ''Healthy Body, Healthy Mind'' which airs on more than 200 [[PBS]] affiliates around the United States.<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomason|first=John|title=Currents A&E Spotlight - Reel Desirable|url=https://issuu.com/jespublishing/docs/brm0512_online|newspaper=Boca Raton Magazine|date=May–June 2012|quote=[...] its "Healthy Body, Healthy Mind" series airing on more than 200 PBS affiliates across the country.|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428190224/https://issuu.com/jespublishing/docs/brm0512_online|archivedate=April 28, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|title=Award Winning Boca Raton Company|url=http://www.pbfilm.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=newsletter.details&ArticleId=2182|work=Palm Beach Film Commission|date=July 13, 2015|quote=[...] HBHM Mind celebrates it’s 10 year anniversary with ITV producing nearly 300 episodes, airing on Public Television since 2004.|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428190805/http://www.pbfilm.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=newsletter.details&ArticleId=2182|archivedate=April 28, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== History ==
Ed Lerner, a former [[ABC News]] documentary maker, founded the company with his wife Ana Cristina Lerner in order to create informational and educational programming that reflected the burgeoning [[Information Age]]. In 1992, ITV produced its first series, ''The Cutting Edge Medical Report'', a documentary medical series which went on to a 10-year run of 200 half-hour episodes which aired on PBS. In 2004, ''The Cutting Edge Medical Report'' was revamped and became ''Healthy Body, Healthy Mind'', a similar series but with an increased focus on health and wellness. As of May 2, 2016, a total of 300 episodes of ''Healthy Body, Healthy Mind'' have aired over the course of 32 seasons on more than 200 public television stations nationwide.
ITV also produced other educational televisions shows focused around children and teen health issues. In 1997, ITV produced ''Hall Pass'', a syndicated teen news show, which ran for one season and featured the first television appearance of then 14-year-old [[Chyler Leigh]] as co-host.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1997-02-04/news/9702060278_1_teens-miami-florida-atlantic-university|title=Stars Are Born - Locally Produced TV Program Hall Pass Finds Talent Close To Home|last1=Eisner|first1=Randi|last2=Cohen|first2=Nina|date=February 4, 1997|quote=Hall Pass episodes will be taped during the spring at Information Television Studios in Boca Raton.|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428200857/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1997-02-04/news/9702060278_1_teens-miami-florida-atlantic-university|archivedate=April 28, 2016|newspaper=South Florida Sun-Sentinel|deadurl=no}}</ref> In 2002, ITV produced ''Kids HealthWorks'', a documentary series on children's health which aired on [[Discovery Health Channel]].<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|title=The National Dairy Council and The American Academy of Pediatrics Partner In New Discovery Health Channel Series Called Kids HealthWorks|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-national-dairy-council-and-the-american-academy-of-pediatrics-partner-in-new-discovery-health-channel-series-called-kids-healthworks-77038517.html|website=prnewswire.com|publisher=PR Newswire|quote=[...] in a new Discovery Health Channel series called Kids HealthWorks.|location=Rosemont, Illinois|date=April 18, 2002|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428202904/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-national-dairy-council-and-the-american-academy-of-pediatrics-partner-in-new-discovery-health-channel-series-called-kids-healthworks-77038517.html|archivedate= April 28, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> In 2005, ITV produced ''E-Venture Kids'', a pre-teen educational television pilot, which aired on more than 40 PBS stations and featured the first television acting appearance of then 10-year-old [[Ariana Grande]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2005-05-05/news/0505041529_1_world-surfing-dream-foundation-pilot|title=World Surfing - Boca Philanthropist Backs TV Show Taking Kids On Computer Adventure|last=Fernandez|first=Mireidy|date=May 5, 2005|quote=The pilot for E-Venture Kids will premiere on WXEL at 8 p.m. Saturday and air on more than 40 other PBS stations nationwide.|access-date=May 2, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151026004821/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2005-05-05/news/0505041529_1_world-surfing-dream-foundation-pilot|archivedate=October 26, 2015|newspaper=South Florida Sun-Sentinel|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Programming ==
=== Original Series === * ''The Cutting Edge Medical Report'' * ''Healthy Body, Healthy Mind'' * ''Kids HealthWorks''
=== Original Pilots === * ''E-Venture Kids''
=== Mini-Series === * ''The Art of Women's Health''
==References== <references/>
==External links== * {{Official website|http://itvisus.com}} * {{imdb company|id=0047032|company=Information Television Network}} * [http://www.healthybodyhealthymind.com ''Healthy Body, Healthy Mind'']

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=June 2016}}
The '''International Planetarium Society, Inc.''' (IPS) is the global association of [[planetarium]] professionals. Its nearly 700 members come from [[List of planetariums|35 countries]] around the world. They represent schools, colleges and universities, museums, and public facilities of all sizes, including both fixed and portable planetariums. The primary goal of the Society is to encourage the sharing of ideas among its members through conferences, publications, and networking. By sharing their insights and creative work, IPS members become better planetarians.
IPS membership is open to anyone interested in planetariums. Members include directors, teachers, technicians, writers, artists, media specialists, digital artists and producers, presenters, vendors, scientists, students, and sponsors and friends of the planetarium dome and its starry sky.
More than 20 regional and national planetarium associations from around the world are affiliated with IPS. Representatives from those affiliates, together with the elected officers, make up the Executive Council, the ruling body of the organization.

[http://www.astronomie.nl/ www.astronomie.nl/] |- | Association of French-Speaking Planetariums (APLF) || [http://www.aplf-planetariums.org/ www.aplf-planetariums.org] |- | Association of Mexican Planetariums (AMPAC) || |- | Association of Spanish Planetariums (APLE) || [http://www.planetarios.org/ www.planetarios.org] |- | Australasian Planetarium Society (APS) || [https://apsplanetarium.com/ apsplanetarium.com] |- | British Association of Planetaria (BAP) || [http://planetaria.org.uk/ planetaria.org.uk] |- | Canadian Association of Science Centres (CASC) || [http://www.canadiansciencecentres.ca/ www.canadiansciencecentres.ca] |- | Chinese Planetarium Society (CPS) || |- | European/Mediterranean Planetarium Association (EMPA) || |- | Italian Association of Planetaria (IAP) || [http://www.planetari.org/ www.planetari.org] |- | Japan Planetarium Association (JPA) || [http://planetarium.jp/ planetarium.jp] |- | Nordic Planetarium Association (NPA) || |- | Russian Planetarium Association (RPA) || [http://www.apr.planetariums.ru/ www.apr.planetariums.ru] |- | Society of the German-Speaking Planetariums (GDP) || [http://www.gdp-planetarium.org/ www.gdp-planetarium.org] |- | United States: Great Lakes Planetarium Association (GLPA) || [http://glpa.org/ glpa.org] |- | United States: Great Plains Planetarium Association (GPPA) || [http://www.spacelaser.com/gppa/ www.spacelaser.com/gppa] |- | United States: Middle Atlantic Planetarium Society (MAPS) || [http://www.mapsplanetarium.org/ www.mapsplanetarium.org] |- | United States: Pacific Planetarium Association (PPA) || [http://sites.csn.edu/planetarium/PPA/ sites.csn.edu/planetarium/PPA] |- | United States: Rocky Mountain Planetarium Association (RMPA) || |- | United States: Southeastern Planetarium Association (SEPA) || [http://www.sepadomes.org/ www.sepadomes.org] |- | United States: Southwestern Association of Planetariums (SWAP) || [http://www.swapskies.org/ www.swapskies.org] |}
== Membership == IPS members receive the quarterly journal ''Planetarian''; attend biennial conferences on even-numbered years; receive conference proceedings, the ''IPS Directory'', and special publications. Member-only benefits are available through the IPS website at [http://ips-planetarium.org/ ips-planetarium.org], where interested persons also can join.
== Publications == ''Planetarian'' is the IPS quarterly membership journal and an important member benefit. In addition to regular features and columnists, it seeks research articles on any aspect of planetarium education (that will be professionally reviewed upon request), the history of planetariums, technological developments, and much more.
Also available: * ''[https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=dir IPS Directories]'': worldwide listing of planetariums and resources * [https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=proceedings Conference Proceedings]: papers and workshops presented at the biennial conferences * [https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=special Special Publications and Reports]: handbooks and resources
== Structure == Elected officers are president, president-elect, past-president, secretary, and treasurer. The officers, along with representatives from the affiliate organizations, make up the Executive Council, the ruling body of the organization.
The current executive officers are: * President, Shawn Laatsch * President-Elect, Mark SubbaRao * Past President, Joanne Young * Secretary, Ann Bragg * Treasurer, Rachel Thompson
All positions are volunteer.
== History<ref>"[https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=a_Engle1982 Historical Aspects of the International Planetarium Society]," Paul R. Engle, ''Planetarian'', Vol. 11 No. 2</ref><ref>"[https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=weinrich40year A Forty-year Perspective of the International Planetarium Society]," Dave Weinrich, ''Proceedings of the 47th Annual GLPA Conference'' in Champaign, Illinois, October 19–22, 2011</ref> == The genesis of what was to become the International Planetarium Society began with a meeting of planetarium educators in 1958 at the Cranbrook Institute in Michigan. Sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF), about 100 delegates from 67 facilities attended. The conference's proceedings were published as ''[https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/pdf-pubs/1958_cranbrook_proceedings.pdf Planetaria and Their Uses for Education]''.
Another meeting was sponsored by the NSF in 1960, this time in Cleveland, Ohio, and resulted in ''[https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/pdf-pubs/1960_cleveland_proceedings.pdf Planetariums and Their Uses for Education, Volume 2].'' At this meeting those attending voted to initiate a national planetarium association called the American Association of Planetarium Operators, but nothing came out of the action.
Regional associations of planetarium educators formed in the 1960s, resulting in the forming of GLPA, MAPS, SWAP, PPA, RMPA, and SWAP, and PAC was formed in Canada.
More than 300 planetarians gathered in 1970 at the Abrams Planetarium at Michigan State University in East Lansing at a meeting called CAPE - the Conference of Planetarium Educators. At this meeting the decision was made to organize a North American planetarium association and publish a journal. By-laws for the International Society of Planetarium Educators were approved in 1971, and the journal, ''Planetarian'', began in 1972. Paul Engle from the University of Arkansas at Little Rock Planetarium became the first president, and the first editor was Frank C. Jettner from the Department of Astronomy at the State University of New York at Albany. Among the articles in the first issue was "Science and Communication" by Isaac Asimov.
== Early Planetarians == The planetarium field's earliest members were those who invented and modified the equipment used to project the stars onto the dome. Among them are * [[Walther Bauersfeld]], often called the "father" of planetariums, for his development of the Zeiss 1 model opto-mechanical projector in 1923 * [[Armand Spitz]], who developed an early inexpensive opto-mechanical projector * [[Richard H. Emmons]], who helped establish more than 23 planetariums
== Awards == The highest award given by IPS is the '''Service Award''', started in 1982. This award is bestowed, from time to time, by the Society upon an individual or institution whose presence and work in the planetarium field has been, through the years, an inspiration to the profession and its members.” Since 1982 there have been 23 people<ref>https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=awardees</ref> awarded with the IPS Service Award.
Similarly, the IPS '''Technology and Innovation Award''' is given by the Society, from time to time, upon an individual whose technology and/or innovations in the planetarium field have been, through the years, used or replicated by other members and/or other planetariums.” The award began in 2009 and 4 persons<ref>https://ips-planetarium.site-ym.com/?page=awardees</ref> have been recognized.
Deserving IPS members also may be named a '''Fellow''' of the Society. To be named, a member must have continuous active membership in good standing in IPS for at least five years and substantial contributions in at least two of the following respects:
* Serving IPS in effective office, diligent and/or devoted committee work, and the organization of conferences and meetings. * Relevant and significant publications and/or conference presentations. * Cooperation with professional societies, organizations and groups which bring attention to the importance of planetariums’ existence. * The development of new methods in the planetarium field.
== See also == [[Planetarium]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.ips-planetarium.org/
[[Category:Planetaria]] [[Category:Astronomy education]]

{{Infobox organization | logo = File:IREX Logo Color-H.png | type = 501(c)3 | key_people = Kristin Lord (President) <ref name=president>[https://www.irex.org/people/kristin-m-lord Kristin M. Lord], IREX.</ref> | footnotes = | name = IREX (International Research & Exchanges Board) | founded_date = 1968<ref name=history>Sherry Lee Mueller and Mark Overmann, [https://books.google.com/books?id=HCMeAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA213&dq=irex+1968&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiuluff6K_WAhUh34MKHe8tBr44ChDoAQgqMAE#v=onepage&q=irex%201968&f=false Working World: Careers in International Education, Exchange, and Development], 2nd ed. (Washington, DC: Georgetown University Press, 2014).</ref> | founder = | location = [[Washington, DC]], [[United States]] | origins = | area_served = International | product = International development | focus = Education, independent media, civil society | method = | revenue = $70,206,999<ref>{{cite web|title=INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & EXCHANGES BOARD INC|url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/223/223087809/223087809_201506_990.pdf|publisher=Foundation Center|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref> | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 400 <ref name=":0"></ref> | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.irex.org www.irex.org] | dissolved = }}
The '''International Research & Exchanges Board''' ('''IREX''') is an international, [[nonprofit organization]] that specializes in global education and [[International development|development]]. IREX works with partners in more than 100 countries.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/22-3087809|title=International Research and Exchanges Board Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Guide Star|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 17, 2017}}</ref>
== History == IREX was established in 1968 by the [[American Council of Learned Societies]], the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Social Science Research Council]], and the [[United States Department of State|US Department of State]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hYOGk3V_L3cC&dq=irex+ford+foundation+acls+-site%3Airex.org&q=irex#v=snippet&q=irex&f=false|title=Cultural Exchange and the Cold War: Raising the Iron Curtain|last=Richmond|first=Yale|publisher=Penn State University Press|year=2004|isbn=|location=University Park, PA|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HeUG-oY709AC&pg=PA246&dq=irex&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiS65W95_LVAhVKQiYKHf70DzA4ChDoAQglMAA#v=onepage&q=irex&f=false|title=Know Your Enemy: The Rise and Fall of America’s Soviet Experts|last=Engerman|first=David|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2009|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Capodilupo|first=Lucia|date=1984|title=IREX in Romania: Overview of Programs to Date and Plans for the Future|url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1028&context=anthro_res_rpt24|journal=Economy, Society, and Culture in Contemporary Romania|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> IREX conducted scholarly exchanges between the US and the Soviet Union until the fall of the Iron Curtain.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hYOGk3V_L3cC&dq=irex+ford+foundation+acls+-site%3Airex.org&q=irex#v=snippet&q=irex&f=false|title=Cultural Exchange and the Cold War: Raising the Iron Curtain|last=Richmond|first=Yale|publisher=Penn State University Press|year=2004|isbn=|location=University Park, PA|pages=}}</ref>
After the collapse of the Soviet Union, IREX implemented projects to support democratic reforms and strengthen organizations.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lJ1p7bJNs_wC&pg=PA257&dq=irex&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUx6u66_LVAhXM4CYKHWrKDR84MhDoAQgyMAI#v=onepage&q=irex&f=false|title=The Power and Limits of NGOs: A Critical Look at Building Democracy in Eastern Europe and Eurasia|last=|first=|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2002|isbn=|editor-last=Mendelson|editor-first=Sarah|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> IREX administered programs to conduct educational exchanges, strengthen civil society in developing countries, increase internet access, and provide training and support to journalists and media organizations.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xMgHDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA24&dq=irex+exchanges&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXwL6zsK_WAhXG3YMKHQE_CTIQ6AEITzAH#v=onepage&q=irex%20exchanges&f=false|title=The Post-Soviet Handbook: A Guide to Grassroots Organizations and Internet Resources|last=Ruffin|first=M. Holt|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=1999|isbn=|location=Seattle|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HXEbvzM5uW4C&pg=PA320&dq=irex&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixu_uc6vLVAhXL4iYKHVO7Dn04HhDoAQhGMAY#v=onepage&q=irex&f=false|title=Civil Society in Central Asia|last=Ruffin|first=M. Holt|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=1999|isbn=|location=Seattle|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dtVCrRifAiEC&pg=PA230&dq=irex&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiAqtyv6PLVAhWKdSYKHZwtCUM4FBDoAQgvMAI#v=onepage&q=irex&f=false|title=Journalism Education in Countries with Limited Media Freedom|last=|first=|publisher=Peter Lang Inc., International Academic Publishers|year=2010|isbn=|editor-last=Josephi|editor-first=Beate|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
== Activities == IREX designs and implements programs that focus on civil society, education, gender, governance, leadership, media, technology, and youth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.devex.com/organizations/international-research-exchanges-board-irex-3236|title=International Research & Exchanges Board (IREX)|last=|first=|date=|website=Devex|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 18, 2017}}</ref>
These programs include the [https://yali.state.gov/washington-fellowship/ Mandela Washington Fellowship for Young African Leaders],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/africa-in-focus/2016/07/19/the-young-african-leaders-initiative-soft-power-smart-power/|title=The Young African Leaders Initiative: Soft Power, Smart Power|last=Schneidman|first=Whitney|date=July 19, 2016|work=Brookings Institution|access-date=September 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/exchange-program-builds-ties-between-us-africa/3771134.html|title=Exchange Program Builds Ties between US, Africa|last=Ritter|first=Mario|date=March 20, 2017|work=Voice of America|access-date=September 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> the [https://www.irex.org/project/world-smarts-stem-challenge World Smarts STEM Challenge],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/03/23/520864034/science-loving-teens-from-ghana-and-d-c-geek-out-together|title=Science-Loving Teens from Ghana and DC Geek Out Together|last=Ingber|first=Sasha|date=March 23, 2017|work=NPR|access-date=September 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/mar/16/dc-ghanian-stem-students-team-up-for-challenge/|title=DC, Ghanian Students Team Up for STEM Challenge, Water Solution|last=Brouillette|first=Julia|date=March 16, 2017|work=Washington Times|access-date=September 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and [https://www.irex.org/project/learn-discern Learn to Discern], which has been discussed for its approach to helping citizens recognize [[disinformation]] and [[fake news]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://cepa.org/reports/winning-the-Information-War|title=Winning the Information War: Techniques and Counter-strategies to Russian Propaganda in Central and Eastern Europe|last=Lucas|first=Edward|publisher=Center for European Policy Analysis|year=2016|isbn=|location=Washington, DC|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.li.com/activities/publications/factual-entertainment-how-to-make-media-literacy-popular|title=Factual Entertainment: How to Make Media Literacy Popular|last=Copeland|first=Paul|publisher=Legatum Institute|year=2016|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/democracy-post/wp/2017/03/31/our-biggest-mistake-in-the-fight-against-fake-news/|title=Our Biggest Mistake in the Fight Against Fake News|last=Jankowicz|first=Nina|date=March 31, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Human development (humanity)|Human development]] * [[International education]] * [[Leadership development]] * [[Media development]] * [[Media literacy]] * [[Positive youth development]] * [[Soft power]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.irex.org/ Official website]

revision.text:
{{primarysources|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox University |latin_name = |image_name = Ishik University.png |image_size = |name = Ishik University |native_name = زانکۆی ئیشک |motto = "The Future is Here" |established = 2008 |type =[[Private University|Private]] |endowment = |staff = |faculty = |president = [[ Dr. Idris Hadi Salih]] |provost = |principal = |rector = |chancellor = |vice_chancellor = |dean = |head_label = |head = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |profess = |city =[[Erbil]] |country =[[Iraq]] |campus =Erbil Campus, Sulaimani Campus |free_label = |free = |colors = {{Color box|#8B0000|border=darkgray}} [[Brown (color)|Brown]]
{{Color box|#FF7E00}} [[Orange (color)|Orange]] |colours = |mascot = |nickname =ISHIK |affiliations = |footnotes = ISO 9001:2008 CERTIFIED |website = [http://www.ishik.edu.iq/ www.ishik.edu.iq] [http://www.ishik.edu.krd www.ishik.edu.krd] |location = 100 mt. Street, near Filkey Baz (Square), across Qazi Muhammad, 44001, Erbil, Krg, Iraq |coor = {{Coord|36|10|14|N|43|57|41|E|region:IQ_type:edu|display=inline,title}} }} [[File:Ishik university new camp erbil.jpg|450px|thumbnail|right|Ishik University Erbil]] '''Ishik University'''([[Kurdish language|Kurdish]] زانکۆی ئیشک- هەولێر or Zankoy Ishik) (IU) ISHIK UNIVERSITY is a private [[university]] established in 2008 in Erbil-Kurdistan, Iraq and owned by local and Turkish investors and educators. Ishik University is granted [[ISO 9001:2008]] Certificate for the Quality Management System and is a member in the Union of Arabic Universities. The University has adopted a Quality Assurance System for ensuring high standards of quality in the teaching, learning and researching processes. Ishik University aims at raising students with global values without ignoring the local ones and it provides a disciplined-work and studying atmosphere and effective teaching processes through providing modern technical facilities and by combining theory with practice. The University offers equal opportunities to students and staff from all nationalities and cultures. Ishik offers the students the opportunity of participating in the 'Double Diploma' and 'Exchange Programs' with other universities around the world. == History of Ishik University == ISHIK University was officially founded in 2008 with a ceremony in which Kurdistan Regional Government Prime Minister Nechirvan Barzani, parliamentarians and bureaucrats, along with parliamentarians from Turkey were present. It was owned by Fezalar Educational Institution, which belonged to the [[Hizmet movement]] founded by [[Fethullah Gülen]]. * In 2008-2009, the education started with the English Prep only with 160 students on the Brayaty Campus located on 60 meter road. During 2009-2010, students were accepted in 5 Bachelor Degree Programs and 8 English Prep Programs. In the same year, the campus was enlarged by the conversion of unused area of an Industrial School and some other buildings into the Education Faculty. This place served as the old campus of the university for about 3 years. * In 2010-2011, all the faculties covering 9 Bachelor Programs, except for Prep School, were carried to the new campus on 100 meter road. The next year, Prep School was also transferred to the new campus where two buildings were in services: main building and the Dentistry Faculty building. During 2011-2013, it became the Center of TOEFL and Continuing Education. * 2014-2015 Academic Year has become a turning point for the University from many angles: - A new building dedicated to the Faculty of Education was constructed. - Ishik Sulaimani campus branch was opened and started education with prep classes of Engineering and Business Faculties. - The Ishik Research Center and Engineering Consultation Bureau were established. - The University was certified with ISO 9001:2008 Quality Management System. - Memorandum of Understanding with more than 40 universities from around 20 countries all over the world was signed. - Student Exchange Programs started with 16 students. - Double Diploma opportunity with University of North American University in Huston Texas was implemented. - Ishik became a member of the Global Engineering Deans Council (GEDC). - Ishik became a member of the Association of Arab Universities. * In 2015-2016, the University started the process of gaining the International Academic Accreditation Certificate for the Civil Engineering Programme. * In 2016-2017, the followings were achieved: - Civil Engineering Programme was granted the International Academic Accreditation Certificate without any conditions by the German Agency ZeVA which is a member in the European Association of Quality Assurance of Higher Education 'ENQA' and a member in the German Union of Accreditation 'ECA'. - Three new Bachelor programmes were established: Surveying and Geomatics Engineering, Petroleum and Mining Engineering and Mechatronics Engineering. - Joint Master Programmes have been opened in cooperation with Erbil Polytechnic University in three specialties: Civil Engineering, Computer Engineering and Mechanical and Energy Engineering. - Staff Exchange Programme was applied with Keylana University in Sri Lanka. - Official recognition of Ishik University by Ministry of Higher Education in Iraq on August 24, 2017. ==Administration== *President Dr. [[Idris Hadi Salih]] *Vice President Dr. [[Mehmet Özdemir]] *Vice President for Admin. & Fin. Dr. [[Wasfi Kahwachi]] Governing bodies of ISHIK University are: the Higher Board of Trustees and the University Council. In addition to these governing bodies, the Academic Evaluation and Quality Assurance Board has been established. In the lower levels, there is a 'Faculty Council' at each faculty and a 'Departmental Board' at each department. ==Units at Ishik== * Prep School * Continuing Education Center * [[CISCO]] Networking Academy * Ishik University Research Center * [[TOEFL IBT]] Test Center * Ishik Career Center * [[Engineering Consultation Bureau]] (IECB) ==Programmes offered at ISHIK University== # Dentistry (5 academic years) # Pharmacy (5 academic years) # Medical Analyses (4 academic years) # Architecture Engineering (5 academic years) # Civil Engineering (4 academic years) # Interior Design Engineering 4 academic years) # Computer Engineering (4 academic years) # Mechatronic Engineering (4 academic years) # Petroleum and Mining Engineering (4 academic years) # Surveying and Geomatics Engineering (4 academic years) # Law (5 academic years) # Business and Management (4 academic years) # Banking and Finance (4 academic years) # Accounting (4 academic years) # International Relations and Diplomacy (4 academic years) # English Language Teaching (4 academic years) # Mathematics Education (4 academic years) # Physics Education (4 academic years) # Biology Education (4 academic years) # Information Technology (4 academic years) ==Internationalization at ISHIK University== In the following, some measures taken by Ishik University to increase the internationalization at all levels are described. * '''Employing International Staff''' There are more than 80 international staff working in both academic and non-academic positions, being from various countries such as Turkey, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, India and USA. * '''Enrollment of International Students''' The rules and regulations of ISHIK University allow international students from any country to join any study programme within the University. In the academic year 2015-2016, the number of international students studying at Ishik University reached 100 students. * '''Applying International Standards such as ISO 9001:2008''' In 2014, the University Council decided to implement ISO 9001:2008 standard at ISHIK University which sets out the criteria for a Quality Management System and which is implemented by over one million companies and organizations over 170 countries. For two years, the documents and the requirements were prepared and fulfilled till finally the external auditors certified Ishik University on June 4, 2015. In addition to increasing the quality within the University, [[ISO 9001:2008]] helps to have access to more memorandums and cooperation with other national and international universities and organizations. * '''Applying Bologna Process''' Ishik University has implemented many parts (but yet not all) of Bologna Process such as: # Credit System # Some Structural Reforms # Internal Quality Assurance # External Quality Assurance # Academic Mobility # Values and Fundamental Principles * '''Students Exchange Programmes''' International Relations Office (IRO) was established at ISHIK University in 2013. IRO is a unit which furthers and supports the exchange of students between the higher education institutions of other countries. So far 22 students from different departments have utilized the Exchange Programme. ==Teaching Language and Credit System== Teaching language at ISHIK University is English, except the law programme which is based on Arabic language. Also Ishik University has adopted ECTS (the European Credit Transfer System) to assess the achievement of expected learning outcomes. At Ishik the academic year is divided into two main terms: fall and spring. ==Universities in Collaboration with ISHIK University== ISHIK University has signed memorandums with 53 universities in various countries such as: Albania, Azerbaijan, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Cambodia, Cyprus, Georgia, Germany, Iraq, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Pakistan, Poland, Romania, Turkey and USA. ==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.ishik.edu.iq/ Ishik University Official website] ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.ishik.edu.iq/ Official Ishik University website] {{Iraqi Kurdistan}} [[Category:Universities in Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Erbil]] [[Category:Private universities and colleges]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2008]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Iraqi Kurdistan]]
