revision.comment: a
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Bell Curve Debate: History, Documents, Opinions | image = File:The Bell Curve Debate.jpg | editors = [[Russell Jacoby]], Naomi Glauberman | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subject = ''[[The Bell Curve]]'' | publisher = [[Random House]] | release_date = 1995 | media_type = Print (paperback) | pages = 720 | isbn = 0-8129-2587-4 | dewey= 305.9/082 20 | congress= BF431 .B3748 1995 | oclc= 31969295 }}
'''''The Bell Curve Debate''''' is a 1995 book edited by [[University of California, Los Angeles]] historian [[Russell Jacoby]] and writer Naomi Glauberman.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Jacoby |editor1-first=Russell |editor2-last=Glauberman |editor2-first=Naomi |title=The Bell Curve Debate: History, Documents, Opinions |date=1995 |publisher=Times Books |location=New York |isbn=0-8129-2587-4 |lccn=95003797 |laysummary=http://www.buffalolib.org/vufind/Record/855715/Reviews |laydate=14 August 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref>
== Summary == A response to ''[[The Bell Curve]]'' (1994), by [[Richard Herrnstein]] and [[Charles Murray (political scientist)|Charles Murray]], ''The Bell Curve Debate'' includes 81 articles by 81 authors. Contemporary authors whose writings are collected in the book include [[K. Anthony Appiah]], [[Gregg Easterbrook]], [[Howard Gardner]], [[Eugene D. Genovese]], [[Nathan Glazer]], [[Stephen Jay Gould]], [[Bob Herbert]], Richard Herrnstein, [[Christopher Hitchens]], [[Irving Louis Horowitz]], [[Arthur Jensen]], [[Leon J. Kamin]], [[Charles Lane (journalist)|Charles Lane]], [[Glenn C. Loury]], [[Richard E. Nisbett]], [[Nell Irvin Painter]], Hugh Pearson, Adolph Reed Jr., [[Carl Rowan]], [[Alan Ryan]], [[Brent Staples]], [[Ellen Willis]], and [[Christopher Winship]]. Jacoby and Glauberman republish historical materials by authors including [[Carl Brigham]], [[Theodosius Dobzhansky]], [[Francis Galton]], [[Walter Lippmann]], [[Karl Pearson]], and [[Lewis Terman]]. The publisher, Times Books, describes the book as a compilation of "the best of recent reviews and essays, and salient documents drawn from the curious history of this heated debate" capturing "the fervor, anger, and scope of an almost unprecedented national argument over the very idea of democracy and the possibility of a tolerant, multiracial America. It is an essential companion and answer to ''The Bell Curve'' and provides scholarship and [[polemic]] from every point of view."
Since publication, ''The Bell Curve Debate'' has been cited by books describing the issues surrounding IQ testing and scores of various social groups in the United States.<ref>{{cite book |title=Intelligence, Genes, and Success: Scientists Respond to the Bell Curve |editor1-last=Devlin |editor1-first=Bernie |editor2-last=Fienberg |editor2-first=Stephen E. |editor3-last=Resnick |editor3-first=Daniel P. |editor4-last=Roeder |editor4-first=Kathryn |editor4-link= Kathryn Roeder |location=New York (NY) |publisher=Springer |date=1997 |isbn=978-0-387-94986-4 |pages=255, 350–351 |laysummary=https://www.springer.com/us/book/9780387949864 |laydate=14 August 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Zenderland |first=Leila |title=Measuring Minds: Henry Herbert Goddard and the Origins of American Intelligence Testing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3s2T1ivKwu0C |accessdate=14 August 2015 |date=23 April 2001 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-00363-6 |page=366 |laysummary=http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/history/history-science-and-technology/measuring-minds-henry-herbert-goddard-and-origins-american-intelligence-testing?format=PB |laydate=14 August 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Race and Intelligence: Separating Science From Myth |editor-last=Fish |editor-first=Jefferson M. |date=2002|publisher=Laurence Erlbaum Associates |location=Mahwah (NJ) |isbn=978-0-8058-3757-5 |pages=92, 196–197 |url=https://www.questia.com/library/106447411/race-and-intelligence-separating-science-from-myth |accessdate=14 August 2015 |subscription=yes |via=[[Questia]] |laysummary=http://www.socialpsychologyarena.com/race-and-intelligence-9780805837575 |laydate=30 August 2010 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Nyborg |editor-first=Helmuth |editor-link=Helmuth Nyborg |title=The Scientific Study of General Intelligence: Tribute to Arthur R. Jensen |date=2003 |publisher=Pergamon |location=Amsterdam |isbn=978-0-08-043793-4 |pages=500, 578, 593 |laysummary=http://store.elsevier.com/The-Scientific-Study-of-General-Intelligence/isbn-9780080437934/ |laydate=16 May 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Jackson |first1= John P. |last2=Weidman |first2=Nadine M. |title=Race, Racism, and Science: Social Impact and Interaction |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4WalMw26IkC |accessdate=14 August 2015 |date=1 January 2004 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-1-85109-448-6 |pages=235, 380 |laysummary=http://rutgerspress.rutgers.edu/product/Race-Racism-and-Science,3110.aspx |laydate=14 August 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Hilliard |first=Constance |title=Straightening the Bell Curve: How Stereotypes about Black Masculinity Drive Research on Race and Intelligence |date=30 April 2012 |publisher=Potomac Books |isbn=978-1-61234-191-0 |page=140 |ref=harv}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
==See also==
* [[History of the race and intelligence controversy]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bell Curve Debate}} [[Category:1995 books]] [[Category:Books about The Bell Curve]] [[Category:Education books]] [[Category:Essay collections]] [[Category:Race and intelligence controversy]] [[Category:Random House books]]

{{Infobox journal | title = The Concord Review | cover = | editor = William H. Fitzhugh | discipline = [[History]] | former_names = | abbreviation = Concord Rev. | publisher = The Concord Review, Inc. | country = United States | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1987–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.tcr.org/tcr/index.htm | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 16415030 | LCCN = 88660102 | CODEN = | ISSN = 0895-0539 | eISSN = }} '''''The Concord Review: A Quarterly Review of Essays by Students of History''''' is an [[academic journal]] dedicated to publishing the research papers of [[high school]] students.<ref>{{cite book |title=Your Name in Print: A Teen's Guide to Publishing for Fun, Profit and Academic Success |last=Harper |first=Elizabeth |authorlink= |author2=Timothy Harper |year=2005 |publisher=St. Martin's Griffin |location= |isbn=978-0-312-33759-9 |page=166 |url= }}</ref> Established in 1987 by [[William H. Fitzhugh (teacher)|William H. Fitzhugh]], a [[Massachusetts]] educator dismayed with the "[[dumbing down]]" of writing standards in American secondary schools, publication in the ''Review'' is considered among the most prestigious awards for high school students.<ref name=Dillon>{{cite news |title=Journal Showcases Dying Art of the Research Paper |author=Sam Dillon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/08/education/08research.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2011}}</ref>
Issued quarterly, the journal publishes research monographs on history topics from high school students from any country, as long as they are in English. Submissions are typically 4000 to 5500 words long, and must be accompanied by a subscription fee (ranging from $70-$150) to the journal in order to be considered.
== Related activities == In addition to publishing the journal, The Concord Review, Inc. engages in a number of other projects. Five outstanding essays per year are awarded the [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] Prize of about $3000.<ref name = Rosemary>{{cite book |title=Teaching the gifted in an inclusion classroom: Activities that work |last=Callard-Szulgit |first=Rosemary S. |authorlink= |year=2005 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Education |location= |isbn=978-1-57886-185-9 |page=142 |url= }}</ref> Fitzhugh also founded the National History Club, with chapters in hundreds of American high schools. Also, The Concord Review, Inc. operates a service called the National Writing Board, which for a fee of $100 will evaluate student writing and forward the results to college admissions committees.<ref name = Proctor/>
== Reception and support == Among others, the ''Review'' has been supported by Boston-based multimillionaire [[John Abele]].<ref name="Dillon" />
Having a paper accepted for publication by ''The Concord Review'' is viewed very favorably by [[University and college admissions|university admissions]] committees,<ref name="Proctor">{{cite book |title=The College Hook: Packaging Yourself to Win the College Admissions Game |last=Proctor |first=Pam |authorlink= |year=2007 |publisher=Center Street |location= |isbn=978-1-931722-81-0 |pages=272 |url= }}</ref> with the Dean of Admissions for [[Harvard University]] considering it equivalent to winning a national mathematics contest. [[Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.]], taped a video testimonial praising the ''Review'' for providing a scholarly venue for high school students.<ref name="Dillon" />
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.tcr.org/tcr/index.htm}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Concord Review}} [[Category:History journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1987]] [[Category:High school research]] [[Category:History education]] [[Category:Quarterly journals]] [[Category:English-language journals]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Theresa Malkiel | image = Theresa Malkiel.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Theresa Serber | birth_date = {{birth date |1874|5|1}} | birth_place = [[Bar, Vinnytsia Oblast]] | death_date = {{death date and age |1949|11|17 |1874|5|1}} | death_place = [[Yonkers, New York]] | occupation = Labor activist, author | religion = | signature = | spouse = Leon Malkiel | children = Henrietta }} '''Theresa Serber Malkiel''' (1874-1949) was a Russian-born American labor activist, [[Women's suffrage in the United States|suffragist]], and educator. She was the first woman to rise from factory work to leadership in the Socialist party. Her 1910 novel, ''The Diary of a Shirtwaist Striker'', is credited with helping to reform New York state labor laws. As head of the Woman's National Committee of the [[Socialist Party of America]] (SPA), she established an annual Woman's Day which was the precursor to [[International Women's Day]]. In 1911, while on a speaking tour of the [[American South]], she called attention to the problem of [[white supremacism]] within the party. She spent her later years promoting [[adult education]] for women workers. == Early life == Theresa Serber was born in Bar, Russia (now Ukraine) on May 1, 1874, one of four sisters. The family moved to the [[Lower East Side]] of New York City in 1891, and seventeen-year-old Theresa went to work as a cloakmaker in a garment factory.Miller (1978), p. 190. == Activism == Soon after her arrival in New York she joined the Russian Workingmen's Club. In 1892 she organized the Infant Cloakmaker's Union of New York, a group of mostly Jewish women, and became its first president.Miller (1978), p. 191. Over the next few years she represented her union in the [[Knights of Labor]], the Central Labor Federation, and the [[United Hebrew Trades]]. Her exposure to the radicalism of the latter two groups reinforced her socialist beliefs, and in 1893 she joined the [[Socialist Labor Party]] (SLP). She was an active member of the SLP for six years, representing her union at the first convention of the [[Socialist Trade and Labor Alliance]].Miller (1978), pp. 192-193. In 1899 she left the SLP and joined the [[Socialist Party of America]] (SPA). Malkiel believed that only socialism could liberate women, and that socialism, in turn, could not survive without the full participation of women. In theory, the Socialist party was committed to equal rights for men and women, but in practice, it made no effort to reach out specifically to women workers and showed little interest in their concerns. Malkiel concluded that socialist women would have to fight their own parallel battle for equality.Miller (1978), pp. 192-3, 197-8, 204. Her 1909 essay, "Where Do We Stand on the Woman Question?" expresses her frustration with this state of affairs:
For the workingwoman of today finds herself between two fires—on the one hand, she faces the capitalist class, her bitterest enemy; it foresees a far-reaching danger in her emancipation and with all the ability of its money power tries to resist her eventual advent into the civilized world. In her anguish the workingwoman turns towards her brothers in the hope to find a strong support in their midst, but she is doomed to be disillusioned, for they discourage her activity and are utterly listless towards the outcome of her struggle.Malkiel (1909), pp. 160-161.
In 1905, Malkiel organized the Women's Progressive Society of Yonkers, which became a branch of the Socialist Women's Society of New York. Although the socialist party was officially opposed to [[separatism]], Malkiel believed a women's organization was necessary to attract women to the party, and as a practice ground for women activists. Women were tired of their limited positions in the party as "official cake-bakers and money-collectors," she said.Miller (1978), p. 194. Meanwhile, she wrote socialist [[propaganda]] leaflets and published numerous articles on socialism and the [[woman question]] in journals such as the ''[[The Socialist Woman|Progressive Woman]]'', ''Machinists' Monthly'', and the ''[[International Socialist Review (1900)|International Socialist Review]]''. She also contributed to the ''[[New York Call]]'', a socialist journal she co-founded with her husband. === Woman's National Committee === Malkiel was elected to the Woman's National Committee of the Socialist party in 1909. She served as a delegate to several conventions, campaigned, wrote pamphlets, and, like [[Rose Pastor Stokes]], helped raise awareness of immigrant women's concerns. She established suffrage clubs designed to appeal to working women and bring them into the party. She also established an annual Woman's Day, starting on February 28, 1909, which was observed by several European socialist parties as well as the SPA.Miller (1978), pp. 195, 197. Woman's Day was the precursor to [[International Women's Day]] which is celebrated each year on March 8.{{cite web |website=United Nations |title=International Women's Day |url=https://www.un.org/events/women/iwd/2008/history.shtml}} In 1909 she worked closely with the [[Women's Trade Union League]] (WTUL) to support the [[New York shirtwaist strike of 1909|New York shirtwaist strike]] with publicity and fundraising. === ''The Diary of a Shirtwaist Striker'' === In 1910, Malkiel published ''The Diary of a Shirtwaist Striker'', a fictionalized account of the shirtwaist strike. She depicted the strike from the point of view of an American-born worker who is initially wary of her immigrant co-workers. Over time she grows closer to them and becomes increasingly aware of the need to win the ballot as well as the strike, and of the need for more solidarity between male and female workers.Miller (1978), p. 198. After the [[Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire]] the following year, the book garnered public attention and helped trigger legislative reforms.{{cite web |website=Jewish Women's Archive |title=Theresa Serber Malkiel, 1874 – 1949 |first1=Emily |last1=Taitz |url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/malkiel-theresa-serber}} Later scholars tended to dismiss the book as propaganda.Basch (1990), p. ix. In 1990 it was reprinted by [[Cornell University Press]] with an introduction by historian Françoise Basch, and received positive reviews from [[Alice Kessler-Harris]], [[Mari Jo Buhle]], and the ''[[ILR Review]]''.Basch (1990), back cover. === Tour of the American South === During a speaking tour of the American South in 1911, Malkiel was appalled to learn that white socialists were practicing [[Racial segregation in the United States|racial segregation]]. In one Arkansas town, she was invited to speak at a gathering of over a thousand African Americans, but party organizers would not allow it. In another, the Socialist local refused to allow African Americans to join. At one event in Mississippi she gave a speech in the pouring rain to a group of dues-paying African-American socialists who were denied entry to the local meeting hall. Her scathing report in the ''[[New York Call]]'' created a stir:Perry (2013), p. 149.
Lord preserve us from this kind of Socialists....We must not preach Socialism to the negroes because the white workingmen are foolish enough to allow their masters to arouse their prejudices against their fellow workers in order to keep them divided so as to play off one against the other.{{cite news |first1=Theresa |last1=Malkiel |newspaper=The New York Call |date=August 21, 1911 |title='Socialists' Despise Negroes in the South |url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call%201911/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call%201911%20-%200610.pdf}}
Despite her occasional use of terms that are now considered ethnic slurs, it is clear she was vehemently opposed to segregation and considered it incompatible with socialism. Her disillusionment in this regard echoes her earlier laments about the party's treatment of women. In modern terms, she supported an early form of [[intersectionality]]. === Other activist work === In 1914, as head of the Socialist Suffrage Campaign of New York, Malkiel organized a mass meeting at [[Carnegie Hall]]. In 1916, she was one of three women appointed by the National Executive Committee to travel across the country campaigning for suffrage. Although the Socialist party was officially opposed to cooperating with suffragist organizations such as the [[National Woman Suffrage Association]], Malkiel supported the idea, stipulating that socialists should always present their views from a socialist perspective.Miller (1978), pp. 200-201. She was suspicious of well-to-do suffragists such as [[Alva Belmont]],Adickes (2000), p. 52. and warned against being distracted by the "[[false consciousness]]" of [[bourgeois]] feminism.{{cite web |first1=Gerald |last1=Sorin |authorlink=Gerald Sorin |website=Jewish Women's Archive |title=Socialism in the United States |url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/socialism-in-united-states}} Malkiel went on two national tours for the Socialist party during [[World War I]], speaking on women's rights and against American involvement in the war. In 1920 she ran for the [[New York State Assembly]] on the Socialist ticket and was narrowly defeated. == Adult education == Malkiel spent the last two decades of her life promoting education for immigrant women and assisting them with [[naturalization]]. She founded the Brooklyn Adult Students Association and directed its classes and summer camp.Miller (1978), p. 204. == Personal life == She married attorney and fellow socialist Leon A. Malkiel in 1900 and moved to Yonkers. She gave birth to a daughter, Henrietta, in 1903.Basch (1990), p. 50. Although no longer a factory worker herself, she remained committed to improving the lives of working women. She died on November 17, 1949. == Selected writings == * {{cite journal |title=Woman and the Socialist Party |journal=The Socialist Woman |volume=I |issue=12 |date=May 1908 |page=8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OvM4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA14-IA18}} * {{cite journal |title=Our Unfortunate Sisters |journal=The Socialist Woman |volume=II |issue=18 |date=November 1908 |page=4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OvM4AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA4-PA4#v=onepage&q&f=false}} * {{cite journal |title=The Emancipation of Women |journal=Machinists' Monthly Journal |volume=XXI |issue=1 |date=January 1909 |pages=33-34 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-nNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA33}} * {{cite journal |title=Where Do We Stand on the Woman Question? |journal=International Socialist Review |volume=10 |pages=159-162 |date=August 1909 |url=https://archive.org/stream/InternationalSocialistReview1900Vol10/ISR-Volume10#page/n169/mode/2up/}} * {{cite journal |title=Which is Better for Women, the Woman Suffrage Movement, or the Socialist Party? |journal=The Progressive Woman |volume=IV |issue=37 |date=June 1910 |pages=6-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zo1EAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA16-IA198}} * {{cite book |title=The Diary of a Shirtwaist Striker: A Story of the Shirtwaist Makers' Strike in New York |publisher=The Co-operative Press |location=New York |date=1910 |url=https://archive.org/details/diaryashirtwais00cogoog}}{{open access}} * {{cite news |newspaper=The New York Call |date=August 21, 1911 |title='Socialists' Despise Negroes in the South: 'Comrades' Refuse to Allow Colored Men in Meeting Halls or Party |url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call%201911/New%20York%20NY%20Evening%20Call%201911%20-%200610.pdf}} * {{cite journal |title=Child Labor |journal=The Railroad Trainman |volume=XXX |issue=10 |date=October 1913 |pages=924-925 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sM3NAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA924}} == References == === Citations === {{reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite book |first1=Sandra |last1=Adickes |title=To Be Young Was Very Heaven: Women in New York Before the First World War |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |date=2000 |pages=52-54 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZI7vCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA52}} * {{cite book |contributor-last1=Basch |contributor-first1=Françoise |contribution=Theresa Serber Malkiel (1874-1949) |first1=Theresa Serber |last1=Malkiel |title=The Diary of a Shirtwaist Striker: A Story of the Shirtwaist Makers' Strike in New York |publisher=Cornell University Press |date=1990 |isbn=9780875461687 |pages=49-52 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=uda30NF0MD8C&pg=PA49}} * {{cite journal |first1=Theresa |last1=Malkiel |title=Where Do We Stand on the Woman Question? |journal=International Socialist Review |volume=10 |pages=159-162 |date=August 1909 |url=https://archive.org/stream/InternationalSocialistReview1900Vol10/ISR-Volume10#page/n169/mode/2up/}} * {{cite journal |first1=Sally M. |last1=Miller |title=From Sweatshop Worker to Labor Leader: Theresa Malkiel, A Case Study |journal=American Jewish History |volume=68 |issue=2 |date=December 1978 |pages=189-205 |jstor=23881894}} * {{cite book |first1=Jeffrey Babcock |last1=Perry |title=Hubert Harrison: The Voice of Harlem Radicalism, 1883-1918 |publisher=Columbia University Press |date=2013 |isbn=9780231511223 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rM7ZD2_B46EC&pg=PA149}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malkiel, Theresa Server}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:American socialists]] [[Category:American suffragists]] [[Category:American women educators]] [[Category:American women writers]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=January 2016}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2016}} }}
[[Image:UNU-OP's Office Building at UNESCO.jpg|thumb|UNU Office at UNESCO building]] The '''United Nations University Office at UNESCO''' serves as academic interface between the [[United Nations University|United Nations University (UNU)]] and its [http://www.unu.edu/system/centres.html Institutes] and [[UNESCO]] and its [https://web.archive.org/web/20100707080126/http://erc.unesco.org/portal/PermanentDelegations.asp?language=en Permanent Delegations] in [[Paris|Paris, France]]. The UNU Office at [[UNESCO]] also develops contacts between UNU and other [[Paris]]-based international organisations as well with [[France|French]] [[academia]].
The aim of the UNU Office at [[UNESCO]] is to make UNU a [[Stakeholder (law)|stakeholder]]{{dn|date=August 2018}} and a full-fledged partner of the [[UNESCO]] system and the diplomatic environment in [[Paris]]. The Office seeks to strengthen existing cooperation and to explore potential joint projects in areas of mutual interest to the two organisations.
To this end, the UNU Office at [[UNESCO]] organises public events aimed at presenting UNU’s activities. It represents UNU at meetings of [[UNESCO]], particularly the spring session of the [http://www.unesco.org/new/en/executive-board/sessions/introduction/ Executive Board] and the [http://www.unesco.org/en/general-conference-35th-session/general-conference/ General Conference], major world conferences as well as more informal meetings.
==External links== * [http://www.op.unu.edu United Nations University Office in Paris - Website] * [https://www.facebook.com/pages/UNU-Office-at-UNESCO/154747577879616 UNU Office at UNESCO Facebook Page] * [https://twitter.com/UNUOP UNU Office at UNESCO Twitter Page] * [http://www.unu.edu United Nations University - Website]
{{United Nations}}
[[Category:Organizations based in Paris]] [[Category:UNESCO]] [[Category:France and the United Nations]]

revision.text:
The '''Vorarlberg School of Architecture''' (German: ''Vorarlberger Schule'') refers to a group of architects and builders founded in 1657 by [[Johann Michael Beer]] in the [[Austria]]n town of [[Au im Bregenzerwald]]. The school remained active in southern [[Germany]] and [[Switzerland]] until the end of the 18th century. Its most important members came from the Beer, Moosbrugger and Thumb families. The Vorarlberg School developed a distinct design for churches known as ''Vorarlberger Münsterschema''. The school is notable for the its skillful blending of buildings (most of which are abbeys) with the surrounding landscape.
==References==
*[http://www.aeiou.at The Culture Information System of the Austrian Ministry of Education, Science and Culture]
[[Category:Architecture schools]]

revision.text:
[[File:Modell von Octopus vulgaris (Gemeiner Krake) -Blaschka-.jpg|thumb|Blaschka model at the Zoological Collection Rostock]] The '''Zoological Collection Rostock''' ('''ZSRO''', German: '''Zoologische Sammlung Rostock''') is a scientific university collection and associated with the [[Zoology|zoological]] department of the [[University of Rostock]], Germany. The collection was founded in 1775 by [[Oluf Gerhard Tychsen]] and is used both for teaching and research. Parts of the collection are open to the public.
== History == [[File:Zoolog. Inst. HRO-20160411 195759.jpg|thumb|Plaque at the Zoological Institute of the Rostock University]] The zoological collection was founded in 1775 by Oluf Gerhard Tychsen, an orientalist and head librarian of the University of Rostock.<ref>Kinzelbach, Ragnar: Die Zoologische Sammlung der Universität Rostock in: Stier und Greif. Blätter zur Kultur- und Landesgeschichte in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Schwerin, Band 13 (2003), S. 196-197</ref> In 1789, the collection became part of the “Academic Museum”. It was relocated to the Universitätsplatz in 1844 after the adoption of parts of the collection of the grand duke in [[Ludwigslust]]. The zoological collection is still located at the Universitätsplatz. Since 2002, it features a public exhibition room with changing special exhibitions.
== Holdings == [[File:Rostocker Pfeilstorch.jpg|thumb|right|The ''Rostocker Pfeilstorch'']] The collection holds about 140.000 series of [[taxa]] from all over the world.<ref>[https://www.zoologie.uni-rostock.de/zoologische-sammlung/zoologische-sammlung/ Homepage of the zoological collection] (German)</ref> The collection focus includes mollusca (ca. 14.000), Polychaeta (ca. 2.500), fish (ca. 2.500), birds (ca. 2.400), and scorpions (ca. 1.000). Furthermore, the collection owns important historical teaching models, including models by the [[Blaschka]] brothers and Ziegler wax models. It is also home to the ''Rostocker [[Pfeilstorch]]'', which provided early evidence for long-distance migration by storks.
== References ==
<references/>
== External links == {{Commons category|Zoological Collection Rostock}} *[https://www.zoologie.uni-rostock.de/zoologische-sammlung/zoologische-sammlung/ Homepage der zoologischen Sammlung] (German)
